docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your article ''Experts Reveal the Secret Powers of Grapefruit Juice'' (March 21) points out that the juice can have unpredictable effects when taken in combination with certain anticholesterol drugs. After I read it, I recalled that I had a craving for grapefruit during my pregnancy and would eat two or three a day.
docs.abstract: Mary Beth James-Thibodeaux letter on March 21 article about drug interaction with grapefruit juice describes her craving for grapefruit during her pregnancy

docs.lead_paragraph: Helen is so tough, her ex-husband, Jerry, reminisces, that he ended up nicknaming her Hell. And at first, in David Marshall Grant's earnest new play, ''Pen,'' that sounds right. Especially with the wizardly J. Smith-Cameron portraying the character as if she were a repeating rifle, the one-liners shooting forth nonstop -- some funny, others leaving a bloody track on their target. But soon it is obvious that Helen is not so much a cruel adult as an angry, cheated teenager. Life hasn't gone her way. She is in a wheelchair, captive to multiple sclerosis and a fear of abandonment by her only child, 17-year-old Matt, with whom she lives in a state of war and anguished love on Long Island in 1969. ''Pen,'' which opened last night at Playwrights Horizons, directed by Will Frears, has a lot to say, too much at times. But it is eloquent about its three characters' relationship to the past. Helen clings to it; Jerry, who abandoned Helen after she could no longer walk, is heading for a new life, like a swimmer speeding away from a sinking boat. The furious Matt, oscillating between infant and adult, understands that future derives from past and that the two are inseparable.

headline.main: Familial Duty vs. Freedom: Struggling to Balance the Heart's Ledger

docs.snippet: "Pen" has a lot to say, too much at times. But it is eloquent about its three characters' relationship to the past.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jordan Farmar became a floor leader on the same day he became a man. He stood in Temple Judea in Tarzana, Calif., a 13-year-old reciting all the prayers he had memorized in Hebrew school. He ignored the 600 people who had come to his bar mitzvah. He focused only on the prayers.

headline.main: The Bruins Let Farmar Do the Talking

docs.abstract: UCLA and point guard Jordan Farmar prepare to face Florida University in men's NCAA basketball tournament final; photos (M)
docs.snippet: U.C.L.A.'s Jordan Farmar became a floor leader on the same day he became a man.

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE day, when the director Rufus Norris was just scraping by in public housing in South London with a wife, a child and another on the way, he went and did something he'd never done before: he bought a copy of a movie. The film, he swears, was ''The Celebration,'' the 1998 Cannes Film Festival favorite directed by Thomas Vinterberg, a founding member of Dogma 95, the Danish film movement that religiously abides by a lengthy set of production rules, including hand-held cameras only and no artificial lighting.

headline.main: A Seat at the Worst Family Dinner

docs.abstract: Article on play Festen by David Eldridge, based on Danish film The Celebration; director Rufus Norris comments; photos (M)
docs.snippet: "Festen" is coming to Broadway with an American cast and, as the director Rufus Norris puts it, an uncertain place in a crowded season.

docs.lead_paragraph: In my 20th week of pregnancy a few years ago, I was informed by my physician that the son I was carrying had Down syndrome. My husband and I never hesitated in our decision to terminate the pregnancy. We already had a disabled child in need of our attention. The issues addressed in Elizabeth Weil's insightful article (March 12) bring up profound moral questions. How do you measure the degree of disability in an unborn child and make an informed decision about denying or allowing that child life? In October of last year, our 15-year-old son committed suicide, following a long struggle with bipolar disorder. Although no prenatal test exists for this illness, I can only wonder what our actions might have been had we been told of his potential suffering. What if we had known that he might choose his own death over a life without peace? And what if we weren't told that we might have the privilege of knowing and loving a deep, smart, beautiful and talented boy for those 15 challenging, but oddly rich, years? I cannot begin to guess what our choice would have been. I only know that through all the heartbreak of his illness and death, we were blessed to parent our son for as long as we did. It seems impossible to put a quantitative value on a life not yet lived. Science both enlightens and burdens us with uncertain knowledge of what might have been. Dana Heinz Perry New York
docs.abstract: Dana Heinz Perry letter comments on Elizabeth Weil's March 12 article on wrongful birth litigation

docs.lead_paragraph: TEENAGE pregnancy, fights with parents, same-sex kissing: so begins another cycle of ''Degrassi: The Next Generation.'' The Canadian series, a chronicle of the so-called lives of a large group of high school kids, embarks on the second half of its fifth season Friday at 8 p.m. The viral success of ''Degrassi'' has not only brought an audience to its broadcaster, MTV Networks' N cable channel, it has also helped shape the channel's image as a destination for teenage viewers. Though the N is in only 48 million homes, new episodes of ''Degrassi'' consistently win their time period against everything else on television among teenagers. Over all, the N's ratings improved between 2004 and 2005 by 35 percent among teenagers. Amy Harris, a director at the media-buying agency Starcom Entertainment, said the channel had etched a place in the age spectrum already well-covered by other MTV Networks channels. ''They've identified this key group between Nickelodeon and MTV,'' Ms. Harris said.

headline.main: Bringing Up Baby Into an R-Rated World

docs.abstract: Article discusses success of MTV Networks' N cable channel, which has huge audience of teenagers; although much of N channel's success comes from running Canadian series DeGrassi: The Next Generation, new series are being developed to retain audience; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The N channel, once the province of preschool, has all growed up into a preferred destination for teenagers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Marlana Reed and Geraldine Westcott were huddled in the corridor of a hospital in the Bronx one recent morning, wrangling over who would be in charge of heroin and who should cover crack. After agreeing, they entered the conference room and sat at the head of a long table. Five first-year doctors on the other side focused the attentive stares they seemed to have honed in medical school.

headline.main: Drug Users Transform Their Hard Lessons Into Tools to Teach Doctors

docs.abstract: Montefiore Medical Center in Bronx institutes program in which female patients from methadone clinics lead seminars for interns concerning substance abuse and its culture; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In the Albert Einstein College of Medicine's residency program at Montefiore Medical Center, substance abuse training may include lessons from those with firsthand experience.
